text:
i want H and L to move to start of line and end of line in zed editor, how to configure it

To configure H and L keys to move to the start and end of line in Zed editor, you'll need to modify your key bindings configuration. Here's how you can do it:

1. Open Zed's Settings:
   - Use Cmd+, (Mac) or Ctrl+, (Windows/Linux)
   - Or click on the menu: Settings â†’ Open Key Bindings

2. Add these key bindings to your configuration:

```json
[
  {
    "key": "H",
    "command": "move_to_line_start",
    "when": "editor.focus"
  },
  {
    "key": "L",
    "command": "move_to_line_end",
    "when": "editor.focus"
  }
]
```

Note: If you have existing key bindings, make sure to add these within the existing array, separated by commas.

These bindings will make:
- H: move to the start of the line
- L: move to the end of the line

Remember that this will override any existing functionality of the H and L keys in normal mode if you're using Vim keybindings.
can i map other vim keys to the keys like ^ and #

Yes, you can map other Vim keys to Zed commands. Here's how you can map various Vim-style movements:

```json
[
  {
    "key": "shift+6", // This is ^
    "command": "move_to_first_non_whitespace",
    "when": "editor.focus"
  },
  {
    "key": "shift+4", // This is $
    "command": "move_to_line_end",
    "when": "editor.focus"
  },
  {
    "key": "shift+3", // This is #
    "command": "search_for_word_backward",
    "when": "editor.focus"
  },
  {
    "key": "shift+8", // This is *
    "command": "search_for_word_forward",
    "when": "editor.focus"
  }
]
```

Common Vim-style mappings you might want to add:
- `^` (shift+6): Move to first non-whitespace character
- `$` (shift+4): Move to end of line
- `#` (shift+3): Search for word under cursor backward
- `*` (shift+8): Search for word under cursor forward
- `0`: Move to absolute beginning of line

Note: The exact commands and their availability may depend on your version of Zed as the editor is still evolving. You can check the available commands in Zed's command palette (Cmd/Ctrl+Shift+P) to see what commands you can map to.
